nodes.text: The distribution and dynamics of money in an economy can be understood using statistical physics: if money is locally conserved and transactions satisfy time-reversal symmetry, the equilibrium money distribution is exponential, and deviations arise from nonconservative or non-symmetric transaction rules and from debt and state interventions
Method: Derive money distribution dynamics with a Boltzmann kinetic equation for pairwise transactions and reduce to a Fokker-Planck (Kolmogorov forward) equation when transaction amounts are small

Result: Under detailed balance (time-reversal symmetry) the stationary solution of the kinetic equation is the Boltzmann-Gibbs exponential distribution P(m) proportional to exp(-m/Tm) with money temperature Tm equal to mean money per agent M/N

Claim: Entropy maximization (Boltzmann principle) subject to fixed total money yields the exponential distribution as the maximal-entropy equilibrium, and entropy increases monotonically under the kinetic dynamics

Claim: If transaction rules are multiplicative or otherwise violate time-reversal symmetry (e.g., transfers proportional to agents' balances), stationary distributions become non-exponential (Gamma-like or with power-law tails)

Evidence: Empirical income data for the USA show a two-class structure: the majority follows an exponential distribution while the high-income tail follows a Pareto power law, consistent with coexisting additive and multiplicative processes

Method / Result: Agent-based simulations starting from equal money balances and additive unit transactions evolve to a stationary exponential distribution due to boundary m>0; initial equality is unstable and lower boundary is crucial for equilibrium

Claim / Context: Differentiate monetary layer (digital conserved accounting tokens) from physical layer (goods and services not conserved); money conservation is an accounting principle preventing free riding and requires boundary conditions to enforce stability

Claim: Debt is distinct from money (debt is a promise, personal, time-stamped, and typically carries interest); allowing unbounded debt removes the lower boundary and leads to unbounded spreading of net worth distribution and no equilibrium

Result / Claim: Debt creation behaves like particle-antiparticle pair creation (money plus matching debt), is statistically irreversible (entropy can grow without bound), interest exacerbates divergence, and debt does not self-stabilizeâ€”restrictions or external interventions are required

Claim: Commercial banks create debt/liabilities for customers (so-called endogenous money creation) but this is not equivalent to exogenous money injected by the state; reserve requirements are a soft constraint and do not impose an absolute cap on debt

Claim / Evidence: Central bank actions (exogenous money creation via purchasing government debt, i.e., monetization and quantitative easing) inject money into the system largely through banks and financial markets, and empirical data link large QE and bailout episodes to increased income concentration in the upper class

Evidence / Result: IRS income data analysis across decades shows spikes in the fraction of income accruing to the top (higher f and Gini) during market bubbles and after QE, supporting the assertion that bailouts and central bank liquidity disproportionately benefit the financial upper class

Conclusion: The ultimate practical source of net monetary profit for capital as a class is state-created money (exogenous injections during crisis monetization), because endogenous debt-driven expansions must ultimately be monetized or default and cannot by themselves produce sustainable net aggregate monetary gains

Limitation / Future direction: The paper focuses on abstract monetary accounting and statistical models; interactions with physical constraints (energy, resource limits) and the changing topology of digital goods production remain important unresolved topics for extending the framework
